title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Some examples that would earn credit include:

· “Between 1800 and 1848, the economy of the United States drastically changed. The growth of manufacturing and the development of new production methods and transportation networks—primarily in the Northeast—resulted in increased demand for goods and resources from across the country, especially cotton from the South, and led many to seek new domestic and international markets for American goods.”

· “Because most of the development caused by the market revolution occurred in Northern cities, the process resulted in widening regional economic and cultural differences in the period from 1800 to 1848.”

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, provided the essay clearly connects them to the prompt:

· The rapid expansion of cotton production in the South as a result of the invention of the cotton gin

· The continued territorial expansion of the United States (Louisiana Purchase, Florida Cession, Mexican-American War)

· Continued desire to expand valuable international trade relationships, especially with Europe and European outposts in the Western Hemisphere such as Cuba

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE – PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848.

The response provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of evidence used might include the following:

· American System

· Erie Canal

· Henry Clay

· Interchangeable parts

· Internal improvements (canals, roads, and railroads)

· Lowell mills

· Nullification Crisis

· Robert Fulton

· First and Second Bank of the United States

· Steam engines

· Tariffs

· Telegraph

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE – USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not support an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

An example of evidence used to support an argument:

· “The construction of canals across the Northeast and Midwest accelerated trade between the regions and made continued westward settlement more profitable.”

· “Debates over whether the federal government should fund internal transportation improvement projects, such as Henry Clay’s American System, contributed to political divisions and regional differences.”

· “The adoption of steam technology in shipping on rivers and in railroads allowed for people and goods to be transported across the United States with greater speed and at a much cheaper price.”

· “The use of factories for manufacturing changed how and where people worked, as women increasingly entered the workforce and a middle class of managers and merchants began to grow.”

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of evidence used might include the following, provided the essay uses the examples in support of an argument about the prompt:

· American System

· Erie Canal

· Henry Clay

· Interchangeable parts

· Internal improvements (canals, roads, and railroads)

· Lowell mills

· Nullification Crisis

· Robert Fulton

· First and Second Bank of the United States

· Steam engines

· Tariffs

· Telegraph

title: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – USES HISTORICAL REASONING
stimulusHtml: To earn the point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.
descriptions: The response does not use historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.

The response uses historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the extent to which the market revolution led to an interconnected national economy in the period from 1800 to 1848.

Examples of using historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

· Explaining how the construction of transportation routes facilitated the growth of towns and cities that came to rely on trade and manufacturing

· Explaining how social and economic changes brought about by the market revolution contributed to the creation of reform movements in the nineteenth century

· Explaining how economic opportunities for women in the market revolution changed how people expected them to behave

· Explaining how the unequal distribution of the benefits of the market revolution contributed to sectional division
